column3: Sing and chant accompanied by music .
[Cut or edit made in tape. Unknown amount of time elapsed].

Welcome to the...welcome to the fourth—third week of the fourth series of our readings here at Sir George w and this one is a special one, partly in that it was, it is being presented by a combination of the daytime Arts Student Association and the evening Arts Student Association, and not simply on the normal schedule. I'm certain that you don't have to be told who Allen Ginsberg w is, and you might think on how lucky it is that you happen to be in Montreal w and he is here at the same time. Last night he was at York University w in Toronto w, and tomorrow he's going to be in Ottawa w, and we're going to sap an awful lot of his energy. Allen is, I think, the most noted poet we've had over the last couple of decades, in the world, and as you're going to find out and as you already know, one of the super-poets in terms of writing poetry, as well. I'd like to give you, without any more cogitation, Mr. Allen Ginsberg.
Applause.

George Bowering w, who I've known a long time, asked me to read a poem that I haven't read through but once before, called "Angkor Wat". So I'll try that. It's middle-sized, like, ten minutes, probably. What it is, is notations taken down in the course of one night in Cambodia w, in Siem Reap w, which is outside of Angkor Wat w, a town outside of the ruins.
[Cut or edit made in tape. Unknown amount of time elapsed].
Reads "Angkor Wat" [from Angkor Wat].
Applause [cut off].
Silence [cut or edit made in tape].

I want to read a couple poems from a book published in Toronto by Anansi Press, or one poem from that. This is written in Saigon w, so it's about a week, yes it's about...the same week, I think. Oh this is...a week before.
Reads “Understand that this is a Dream” [from Airplane Dreams].
Silence [cut or edit made in tape].
I've been working on Blake's w Songs of Innocence w and Experience w, making tunes, or tuning the songs, so I'd like to sing some.
Performs "(a) Introduction / (b) The Shepherd”, accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
Singing them in the order in Experience, that they're in the book, what follows is "The Echoing Green".
Performs "The Echoing Green", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
“The Little Boy Lost" and "The Little Boy Found".
Performs "The Little Boy Lost" and "The Little Boy Found", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
Performs "The Blossom", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
From Experience, the first song is "Hear the Voice of the Bard".
Performs "Hear the Voice of the Bard", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later as “Introduction” on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
And the last song in Experience...
Performs "Introduction", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
And last from Innocence, "The Laughing Song".
Performs "The Laughing Song", accompanying himself on harmonium [recorded later as “b) Laughing Song” on Songs of Innocence and Experience].
Applause [cut off].
